{{Use British English|date=August 2011}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}}

[[File:Golden coat of arms of Singapore (cropped) - 20081001.jpg|thumb|The coat of arms of Singapore depicted on the main gate of the [[Istana (Singapore)|Istana]]]]
The '''coat of arms of Singapore''' was adopted in 1959, the year [[Singapore]] became self-governing within the [[British Empire]]. The committee that created it, headed by [[Toh Chin Chye]], then deputy prime minister, was also responsible for the [[Flag of Singapore|national flag]] and the [[Majulah Singapura|national anthem]]. At the centre of the emblem is a red shield bearing a white crescent and five white stars (representing various national ideals including multiculturalism), supported by a [[Asiatic lion|lion]] and a [[Malayan tiger|tiger]] (representing Singapore and [[Malaysia]] respectively); below them is a blue ribbon inscribed with ''[[Majulah Singapura]]'' in gold. While the use of the coat of arms is restricted to the government, the symbol enjoys wide use on the [[Singapore dollar|national currency]] and state decorations, and appears on the cover of the [[Passport of Singapore|national passport]].
The '''coat of arms of Singapore''' was adopted in 1959, the year [[Singapore]] became self-governing within the [[British Empire]]. The committee that created it, headed by [[Toh Chin Chye]], then deputy prime minister, was also responsible for the [[Flag of Singapore|national flag]] and the [[Majulah Singapura|national anthem]]. At the centre of the emblem is a red shield bearing a white crescent and five white stars (representing various national ideals including multiculturalism), supported by a [[Asiatic lion|lion]] and a [[Malayan tiger|tiger]] (representing Singapore and [[Malaysia]] respectively); below them is a blue ribbon inscribed with ''[[Majulah Singapura]]'' in gold. While the use of the coat of arms is restricted to the government, the symbol enjoys wide use on the [[Singapore dollar|national currency]] and state decorations, and appears on the cover of the [[Passport of Singapore|national passport]].
Line 16: Line 17:
== Uses ==
== Uses ==
[[File:Singapore 10 cent coin.jpg|thumb|150px|Reverse of the 10 cent coin, with the coat of arms in the centre]]
[[File:Singapore 10 cent coin.jpg|thumb|150px|Reverse of the 10 cent coin, with the coat of arms in the centre]]
â
[[File:Golden coat of arms of Singapore (cropped) - 20081001.jpg|thumb|The coat of arms of Singapore depicted on the main gate of the [[Istana (Singapore)|Istana]]]]
 
In 1985 the [[Monetary Authority of Singapore]] (MAS) began to issue their second series of coins. The coat of arms is displayed on the reverse side of these coins, surrounded by an inscription comprising the name of Singapore in the four official languages (Chinese, Malay, Tamil and English) and the year of minting. In 1987 the dollar coin entered circulation with this same pattern.<ref name=coin>{{cite web|url=http://www.mas.gov.sg/currency/currency_info/coins/second_series/Singapore_Circulation_Coins_Second_Series.html |title=Singapore Circulation Coins â Second Series |accessdate=2008-12-24 |date=19 March 2007 |publisher=Monetary Authority of Singapore }}</ref> According to the MAS, the coat of arms has also appeared on all Singaporean banknotes since the "Orchid" series of 1967.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mas.gov.sg/currency/currency_info/notes/orchid_series/Singapore_Circulation_Notes_Orchid_Series.html |title=Singapore Circulation Notes â Orchid Series |accessdate=2008-12-24 |date=19 March 2007 |publisher=Monetary Authority of Singapore }}</ref> State decorations of Singapore also depict the coat of arms on the medallions. For example, the medallions of the [[Darjah Utama Temasek]] and the [[Sijil Kemuliaan]] use the full achievement of arms,<ref name=temasek>{{cite web|url=http://www.pmo.gov.sg/NationalHonoursandAwards/Darjah+Utama+Temasek+(The+Order+of+Temasek).htm |title=National Honours and Awards â The Order of Temasek |accessdate=2008-12-24 |date=11 December 2008 |publisher=Office of the Prime Minister of Singapore }}</ref><ref name=certhonour>{{cite web|url=http://www.pmo.gov.sg/NationalHonoursandAwards/Sijil+Kemuliaan+(The+Certificate+of+Honour).htm |title=National Honours and Awards â The Certificate of Honour |accessdate=2008-12-24 |date=26 September 2008 |publisher=Office of the Prime Minister of Singapore }}</ref> while the [[Darjah Utama Bakti Cemerlang]] medal displays the shield.<ref name=cemerlang>{{cite web|url=http://www.pmo.gov.sg/NationalHonoursandAwards/Darjah+Utama+Bakti+Cemerlang+(The+Distinguished+Service+Order).htm |title=National Honours and Awards â The Distinguished Service Order |accessdate=2008-12-24 |date=26 September 2008 |publisher=Office of the Prime Minister of Singapore }}</ref>
In 1985 the [[Monetary Authority of Singapore]] (MAS) began to issue their second series of coins. The coat of arms is displayed on the reverse side of these coins, surrounded by an inscription comprising the name of Singapore in the four official languages (Chinese, Malay, Tamil and English) and the year of minting. In 1987 the dollar coin entered circulation with this same pattern.<ref name=coin>{{cite web|url=http://www.mas.gov.sg/currency/currency_info/coins/second_series/Singapore_Circulation_Coins_Second_Series.html |title=Singapore Circulation Coins â Second Series |accessdate=2008-12-24 |date=19 March 2007 |publisher=Monetary Authority of Singapore }}</ref> According to the MAS, the coat of arms has also appeared on all Singaporean banknotes since the "Orchid" series of 1967.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mas.gov.sg/currency/currency_info/notes/orchid_series/Singapore_Circulation_Notes_Orchid_Series.html |title=Singapore Circulation Notes â Orchid Series |accessdate=2008-12-24 |date=19 March 2007 |publisher=Monetary Authority of Singapore }}</ref> State decorations of Singapore also depict the coat of arms on the medallions. For example, the medallions of the [[Darjah Utama Temasek]] and the [[Sijil Kemuliaan]] use the full achievement of arms,<ref name=temasek>{{cite web|url=http://www.pmo.gov.sg/NationalHonoursandAwards/Darjah+Utama+Temasek+(The+Order+of+Temasek).htm |title=National Honours and Awards â The Order of Temasek |accessdate=2008-12-24 |date=11 December 2008 |publisher=Office of the Prime Minister of Singapore }}</ref><ref name=certhonour>{{cite web|url=http://www.pmo.gov.sg/NationalHonoursandAwards/Sijil+Kemuliaan+(The+Certificate+of+Honour).htm |title=National Honours and Awards â The Certificate of Honour |accessdate=2008-12-24 |date=26 September 2008 |publisher=Office of the Prime Minister of Singapore }}</ref> while the [[Darjah Utama Bakti Cemerlang]] medal displays the shield.<ref name=cemerlang>{{cite web|url=http://www.pmo.gov.sg/NationalHonoursandAwards/Darjah+Utama+Bakti+Cemerlang+(The+Distinguished+Service+Order).htm |title=National Honours and Awards â The Distinguished Service Order |accessdate=2008-12-24 |date=26 September 2008 |publisher=Office of the Prime Minister of Singapore }}</ref>
